TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE AT A GLANCE  

 

 

  

I. 

THE ONGOING AND ENSUING PROJECTS 

1. 
The Secondary Education Sector Investment Program (SESIP) (2013–2023) will support 
the  government’s  reform  of  secondary  education  (grades  6–12)  into  a  system  that  builds  the 
foundation  for  a  skilled  labor  force  and  prepares  youths  to  meet  the  requirements  of  a  rapidly 
developing  economy. 1  Tranche  1  (2013–2018)  and  Tranche  2  (2015–2018)  are  being 
implemented. Tranche 3 of SESIP supports subsets of the government’s Secondary Education 
Development Program (SEDP) (2018–2023) which incorporated the Secondary Education Sector 
Road Map prepared by SESIP. The impact will be a more efficient, equitable, and higher quality 
secondary  education  system.  The  project  aims  at  improved  student  outcomes  in  secondary 
education and effectiveness of the secondary education system delivered through (i) enhanced 
quality  and  relevance  of  secondary  education, (ii)  increased  equitable  access  and  retention  of 
secondary education, and (iii) strengthened secondary education management and governance. 
Tranche 3 will have $225 million funded from Asian Development Bank (ADB)’s ordinary capital 
resources.2 The key features are (i) results-based approach with the use of disbursement-linked 
indicators,  (ii)  use  of  the  country  system  in  financial  management  and  procurement,  (iii) 
strengthened fiduciary oversight arrangement and management, (iv) introduction of single budget 
system, and (v) adoption of sector-wide approach.3 The World Bank will provide cofinancing of 
$500  million  funded  from  the  International  Development  Association,  and  $10  million  grant 
financed  by  the  Global  Financing  Facility.  Tranche  3  is  included  in  ADB’s  country  operations 
business plan for Bangladesh, 2018–2020.4 
 
2. 
Tranches 1 and 2 of SESIP have already implemented initiatives to strengthen the country 
systems. First, SESIP introduced the National e-Government Procurement (e-GP).5 The Ministry 
of  Education  (MOE)  was  selected  as  one  of  the  pilot  ministries,  and  620  national  competitive 
bidding contracts were successfully awarded through e-GP. Introducing e-GP totally changed the 
conventional procurement practice in secondary education. It strengthens security, competition, 
transparency,  accountability,  and  efficiency  in  the  procurement  process.  Second,  on  financial 
management,  SESIP  successfully  introduced  the  centralized  and  internet-based  financial 
management  information  system,  Integrated  Budget  and  Accounting  System  (IBAS)++,  in  the 
secondary  education  sector,  as  MOE  was  also  selected  as  a  pilot  ministry. 6  With  IBAS++, 
secondary  education  system  has  improved  in  budget  preparation,  execution,  and  accounting. 
While good progress has been made, the system still needs continuous capacity development to

II. 

THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 

Justification 

Outputs and Activities  

 
A. 
 
3. 
The  government  requested  the  technical  assistance  (TA)  to  strengthen  the  fiduciary 
management of SEDP. The program will use the government’s treasury system for disbursement, 
financial  management,  and  procurement  system.  To  mitigate  fiduciary  risks  associated  with 
having  the government manage funds  and  account for  program  expenditures, the government 
and  ADB  agreed  on  a  comprehensive  fiduciary  oversight  arrangement  for  SEDP.  They  also 
agreed on the implementation of an action plan to improve practices in procurement and financial 
management. The TA for the investment programs will specifically support capacity development 
in fiduciary risk management.  
 
The  transaction  TA  will  help  improve  the  government’s  fiduciary  risk  management  and 
4. 
capacity at central and local levels. It will help develop the capacity to implement the ongoing and 
ensuing projects. The TA is included in ADB’s country operations business plan for Bangladesh, 
2018–2020.8 
 
B. 
 
Output 1: Capacity in fiduciary management improved.  The TA will support annual 
5. 
fiduciary reviews (AFRs) in 2019, which will examine annual financial statements and reports, and 
conduct  in-depth  reviews  of  fiduciary  risks  identified  in  the  action  plans.  These  risks  may  be 
sector-specific, such as payroll processing and school grants. There may also be issues raised 
by  reviews  and  audits  conducted  by  the  executing  agencies  and  the  comptroller  and  auditor 
general. The AFRs will include post-procurement review of at least 20% of the contract awards. 
It  will  identify  key  areas  which  needs  capacity  development  in  fiduciary  risk  management  and 
practices  in  procurement  and  financial  management,  including  preparing  satisfactory  financial 
statements  and reports. Recommendations  of the  AFRs  will  focus  on short-term  and medium-
term action plans for institutional capacity development. These would include national seminars 
on  risk  management  in  sector-specific  areas  for  secondary  education  agencies,  and  training 
workshops of local level stakeholders that have weak internal control capacity or large volume of 
transactions. 
 
6. 
Output  2:  Single  budget  system  smoothly  introduced.  The  TA  will  support  the 
introduction of a single budget system in the program. To strengthen the financial reporting and 
monitor the program’s financial management on the single budget, the TA will support, guide, and 
monitor the government’s implementation of the Procurement and Financial Management Action 
Plan. One of the key outputs will be a technical guideline on single budget for implementation for 
the  program.  The  TA  also  supports  in  preparing  satisfactory  financial  statements  and  reports, 
following-up actions on audit observations, and preparing audit reports. Technical consultations 
and capacity building will start in the ongoing projects such as Tranche 1 and 2. 

                                                
7   The first year’s audit reports (2014) were satisfactory. The qualified audit reports in 2015 and 2016 do not show the 
information on program budget heads on eligible expenditure. Submission of the audit reports were also delayed. 
8   ADB. 2017. Country Operations Business Plan: Bangladesh, 2018–2020. Manila. This originally included “Supporting 
Primary and Secondary Education Investment Projects” as one of 2018’s non-lending programs. The TA is being 
processed only for secondary education sector in responding to urgent needs of the government.   

 

  

3 

Cost and Financing 

Implementation Arrangements 

C. 
 
7. 
The  TA  is  estimated  to  $500,000  which  will  be  financed  on  a  grant  basis  by  ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The key expenditure items are listed in Appendix 
1.  The  government  will  provide  counterpart  support  in  the  form  of  counterpart  staff,  data  and 
information access, facilitation of liaisons with stakeholders, and other in-kind contributions.   
 
D. 
 
8. 
ADB will administer the TA. The Human and Social Development Division of South Asia 
Department will select, supervise, and evaluate consultants. MOE will be the executing agency 
and  Directorate  of  Secondary  and  Higher  Education  will  be  the  implementing  agency.  SEDP 
Coordination Unit in MOE will facilitate coordination between the Secondary and Higher Education 
Wing and Technical and Madrasah Wing. The Directorate of Secondary and Higher Education 
Procurement and Finance Wing assisted by SEDP Program Support Unit, acts as a focal point. 
The government, ADB, and the World Bank will jointly develop and agree on a detailed AFR terms 
of reference each year. Outputs of the review will also be jointly discussed and agreed. Agreed 
actions will be included in the updated Procurement and Financial Management Action Plan. 
 
9. 
The  proposed  TA  will  be  implemented  over  24  months,  from  11  December  2017  to  10 
December 2019. The disbursements will be made in accordance with ADB's Technical Assistance 
Disbursement  Handbook  (May  2010,  as  amended  from  time  to  time).  The  implementation 
schedule is in Table 2.

person-month  of  international  and  4  person-months  of  national  inputs  through  a  pool  of 
consultants whose expertise will be defined as the need arises.  
 

III. 

THE PRESIDENT’S DECISION 

 
11. 
The  President,  acting  under  the  authority  delegated  by  the  Board,  has  approved  the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 on a grant basis to the 
People’s Republic of Bangladesh for Improving Secondary Education Sector Management, and 
hereby reports this action to the Board.
